Snow everywhere as we head west on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.
Through Cook Forest in northwestern part of Pa., which contains largest stand of virgin timber in the state.

blocks.text: February 19 - 21, 1960; Trip to Virginia...Gordon, Nancy and Louise. While Nancy spends the week end with a friend in Charlottesville, Gordon and Louise roam the mountains. Approximately 700 miles.
Old-style fences in northern Va.
The Monticello Graveyard
Monticello, home of Thomas Jefferson, stands on hilltop affording magnificent view of surrounding countryside. Nearby is Jefferson's grave.

blocks.text: The Shenandoah Valley covered with one of heaviest snows in recent years.
Peanuts near Roanokoke...and hamburgers near Charlottesville.
Crossing the Blue Ridge Mountains from Waynesboro to Charlottesville.
On the way home, after having picked up Nancy, the Pottomac River at Point of Rocks, on way to Frederick, Md.
End - trip to Virginia.

blocks.text: February 29, 1960 – Educators Mutual Life Insurance Company holds groundbreaking observance for new home office building on Lincoln Highway East.
Gordon gets a turn at the shovel.
Cold, windy day.
Pres. Laurence Strickler makes groundbreaking address.
March 3, 1960 - a foot of snow descends on Lancaster County, accompanied by high winds and deep drifts. Pictures show Louise and Kitty.

blocks.text: March 15 - 20, 1960; Gordon and Walter McClair drive to Atlanta, Georgia, to attend convention of Georgia Education Association. Convention l,700 miles. Approximately 1,700 miles.
Long bridge on Route 301 across the Potomac River.
March 13 - Gordon and Kitty visit Cindy (shown) at Penn State, where she is a first year student.
Tobacco country... typical square barns and crude homes (generally with worn out auto and T-V aerial).
The long—under—construction Hartwell Dam across the Savannah River between South Carolina and Georgia....seen in rain and mist...
Walt checks the amount of mud and slush deposited on the exterior of the car.

blocks.text: The convention is ended...we press homeward through northern Georgia which has recently experienced more snowfall than in the memory of oldest residents. We enter a region which is a part of the TVA system of dams for generation of electric power. We begin to worry about getting through the mountains.
Mountain lake created by TVA dam.
Tourist village of Cherokee is almost completely deserted...most mountain roads still closed by snow....we have doubts about getting to Asheville.

Gordon presides at the business sessions... here with Karl Richards as speaker. ...as speaker.
Time out for play and relaxation (Kitty in foreground).......

(Right) Frank Blakeslee in Lancaster; (left, below) with the George Englands in Findlay; (right, below) the Bill Nell family in Xenia. No pictures are available of the Robert Tromps in Cuyahoga Falls.

blocks.text: October 9 - 12, 1960; Gordon and Kitty on trip through New York and Vermont to see fall foliage. Refer to special book on this and other trips.
Not a good picture (car too fast), but here are Vice President and Mrs. Nixon in Lancaster during Nixon's unsuccessful bid for the presidency.
October 22 - 23: late season week end with the Demis at Beach Haven Terrace, N. J.
November 5 – 6: Gordon, Kitty, Nancy and Louise visit Cindy at Penn State...hope to see Maryland–Penn State football game quelled by rain. Covered bridge in Juniata County seen on way home.

blocks.text: Cindy performs her chores in preparation for return to college after semester vacation.

January 28, 1961 - Nancy steps sprightly forward to receive her B. S. in Education degree in mid-year exercises at Millersville State College. She has completed her courses in 3½ years with the aid of summer school. Commencement exercises have been delayed a week due to the heavy snow. Actually, Nancy has already been teaching for a week as a third grade teacher at Stevens School in the Lancaster City School District.

blocks.text: Pictures above and immediately right show: site of home of Samuel Lincoln, one of the first Lincolns to settle in America, kinsman of Abraham Lincoln; one of many magnificent 18th century square houses in town; the old Ship Church, built in 1681, said to be oldest church continually in use in United States. Hingham.

Right and below: we bypass Plymouth (having been there before) and enter Cape Cod. The girls go wading in the waters of Cape Code Bay...discover and brandish some sort of minor sea monster. Gordon and Kitty suggest gently that they put it down.

blocks.text:
Out on the Cape is Eastham,
boasts the oldest windmill
on the Cape (1793). The only
other such windmill we have
seen was on Long Island.

Much of this area will become
a part of the projected Cape
Cod National Seashore, which
the natives accept with mixed
enthusiasms.
Three miles from Eastham is Nauset light and cliffs overlooking the Atlantic. Here Thoreau began his thirty-mile walk along the shore to Provincetowntown.

Pilgrim Memorial,
Provincetown, where Pilgrims landed before Plymouth.
Cape Cod light near North Truro...high over ocean.

Second night motel beyond New Bedford, Mass... unusual shortage of motels this section of state....picture taken in morning after driving late the night before.
One of two automobile bridges across Cape Cod Canal...this one the northern one at Sagamore. Almost dark; lights already turned on.

blocks.text: This book closes at the mid-year mark of 1962. Nancy, a teacher in Stevens Elementary School, is 22 yrs., 7 mos. old; Cindy has just completed her junior year at Penn State University, is 20 yrs., 8 mos. old; Kathy, having completed her freshman year at Millersville State College, is 18 yrs., ½ mos. old; Louise is 15 yrs., 10⅛ mos. old, has just finished her sophomore year at Manheim Township High School.

July 5, 1962 - Off for California Early in the morning Kathy, Marnie Weaver and Carol Jones load the Weavers' station wagon for a two months' trip to California where they will work for a month in a cannery and spend the rest of the time seeing the Great West. Kitty and Cindy bid them good-by in their night clothes.
